Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Functional Nanomaterials for Sustainable Energy Solutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award provides Ph.D. students at the University of South Carolina at Columbia with the unique training and skill sets to advance the science and engineering of nanomaterials for sustainable energy generation. Trainees are collaborating in interdisciplinary research teams to receive a technical education in alternative energy production and to gain experience in technology commercialization, entrepreneurship and science communication.

Intellectual Merit: Three main research areas direct trainees to design materials that can be applied to energy conversion involving: (1) transformation of carbon dioxide into liquid fuels; (2) conversion of biomass feedstock to liquid fuels; and (3) modifying solar energy into electricity. Trainees engage in problem--?]based learning and use case studies to address each research question through research and coursework. While exploring the basic underlying physical laws and engineering constraints for their research areas, students are participating and competing in a new campus innovation program.

Broader Impacts: This project?fs emphasis on entrepreneurship and strong technical training is preparing trainees to take leadership roles within the fast growing renewable energy industries and existing fossil fuel infrastructure. The University of South Carolina at Columbia?fs campus programs and partnership with North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, encourage the participation of underrepresented groups in this project. Additionally, trainees are engaging in outreach activities with the South Carolina Governor?fs School for Science and Mathematics, to provide research opportunities and mentoring to STEM high school students.

IGERT is an NSF--?]wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to establish new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries, and to engage students in understanding the processes by which research is translated to innovations for societal benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the center of most existing and future technologies for making energy generation more sustainable are functional nanostructured materials that facilitate the various conversion processes required to achieve this goal. Their discovery, development, and large-scale deployment will require intimate collaboration between chemists, physicists, materials scientists, and engineers with attention paid to how these new (in some cases disruptive) technologies impact economics, policy, and society. To meet these challenges, the IGERT program at USC aimed to produce a cohort of PhDs with the unique training and skillsets to advance the science and engineering of materials for sustainable energy generation. Thus, the Project Objectives were to produce PhDs (1) trained in and comfortable with collaborating on interdisciplinary research teams of scientists and engineers; (2) with a broad technical education in the science and engineering that underpins alternative energy production extending beyond their research specialization area; (3) with formal experience in entrepreneurship, including intellectual property development and opportunities and barriers to commercialization; (4) with a broader vision for the societal, economic, political, and global impacts of their research; (5) who communicate effectively with both technical and non-technical audiences through various forms of outreach; and (6) who can  live and work effectively internationally. The main research focus was to develop a scientific and engineering framework for the design of materials and their utilization in various types of energy conversion. Three different research thrusts (RTs) focus on various aspects of the problem, and take advantage of the strengths of core faculty. RT 1 deals with the conversion of CO2 to liquid fuels, using a combination of electrochemical and heterogeneous catalytic approaches. RT2 deals with catalytic materials for the conversion of biomass feedstock to liquid fuels or fuel additives.  RT 3 focuses on novel materials for photovoltaic conversion of solar energy into electricity.  Thus, RT 1 made fossil fuel utilization more sustainable by reducing CO2 emissions while simultaneously storing energy in liquid form, while RTs 2 and 3 developed the science and engineering required to efficiently convert two different renewable sources into electricity and fuel. In their coursework, students took a series of one credit hour modules that helped to enable their study of the science and engineering related to materials and energy generation. The technical background was augmented by coursework and activities focused on entrepreneurship and innovation, with emphasis on commercialization and public policy considerations. Finally, short term international research internships in Japan, China, Thailand, South Korea, Germany and Austria supplemented their research and educational experience, providing them a unique global experience through which to understand their research efforts.

 

For the entire program, 23 IGERT students have been trained, with 8 having already earned their PhD, and the rest on track to graduate within the next two years, by the end of 2021. These students have so far generated 40 peer-reviewed publications, 4 patent applications, and 51 presentations at technical meetings.  In addition, the program developed several novel educational modules dealing with renewable energy, entrepreneurship, public energy policy, and preparation for research.  These courses have been integrated into the educational structure within some participating departments at USC.  Finally, 18 of the 23 students participated (or will participate in the near future) in multi-month international research internships, providing them with a true global perspective on the research endeavor and its impact on their field.
